I.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PROJECT PREPARATION 
A.  Justification 
  A transaction technical assistance (TRTA) is required to (i) conduct due diligence in 
different aspects (Table 2 of Memorandum) of the proposed additional financing for the ongoing 
loan,  thereby  enhancing  readiness  of  the  ensuing  loan  project;  and  (ii)  mitigate  a  risk  in 
environmental safeguard monitoring.

I.  POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
Targeting classification: General Intervention (GI) 
A. Links to the National Poverty Reduction & Inclusive Growth Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The development policy framework of the Government of Bangladesh envisages sustainable development and 
moving towards a middle-income threshold by year 2021.a The per capita electricity consumption in Bangladesh is 
only 371 kilowatt-hours (kWh) (2015), lower than its neighboring countries. b Electricity consumption is projected to 
grow at an annual rate of 11% during 2018–2020 and 6% during 2021–2030.c The demand for electricity has been 
rising rapidly with the growth in per capita income, increasing industrialization and the expansion of the agriculture 
and commercial sectors. Despite 91% of the population having access to electricity as of fiscal year (FY) 2018, 
inadequate supply of electricity remains a primary constraint on economic growth and poverty reduction in 
Bangladesh. Recognizing the need to further industrialize and raise the living standards of the people, the 
Government of Bangladesh has set a goal of providing electricity to all by 2021, and to scale up the transmission 
and distribution network to cater to an expected power demand of more than 30,000 MW by 2030.  
The development policies of the government and particularly its energy policies are consistent with the country 
partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for Bangladesh, which focuses on addressing major constraints for sustaining 
economic growth, environmentally sustainable growth, good governance and capacity development, and regional 
cooperation.  It also  emphasizes on  easing  infrastructure  constraints  through  transformational investments, 
improving human capital through skills development, promoting economic corridor development, improving rural 
livelihoods and providing climate and disaster resilient infrastructure. In addition, promoting gender equality and 
improving private sector participation and improving governance are key cross-cutting priorities. 
In the energy sector, the assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be extended to strengthening the 
transmission and distribution infrastructure and enhancing access to power to meet the national target of increasing 
a ccess to electricity of households, from 76% in 2017 to 100% by 2021. 
The Bangladesh Power System Enhancement and Efficiency Improvement Project d and additional financing are 
in line with the national and sector needs and priorities of the government and the country partnership strategy for 
Bangladesh. It will enhance the reliability and efficiency of the transmission and distribution network for better 
utilization  of expanding  power  generation capacity  to meet  the  growth in electricity  demand.  The  project 
components include support for the transmission system development in southern Bangladesh, distribution system 
rehabilitation,  expansion  and  rural  electrification,  and  technical  support  for  a  variety  of  studies  including 
development of projects from renewable energy sources, energy efficiency improvements, and enhancement of 
regulatory initiatives. 
B. Results from the Poverty and Social Analysis during Due Diligence 
1.  Key poverty and social issues. In Bangladesh, the population living below the national poverty line was 24.3% 
in 2017; with 14.8% of the population having purchasing power parity below $1.90 a day.e Middle-income 
households comprise another 15% to 25% across the subproject areas and 25% of households in the upper income 
categories. The average landholding size is estimated at 0.98 acres, which is hardly sufficient for the sustenance 
of large families. he monthly incomes of 72.6% of the households in subproject areas are less than Tk20,000 and 
of them, 25% have monthly incomes of less than Tk10,000. The rate of unemployment ranges from 10% to 30% 
across subproject impact areas, largely due to comparatively low educational levels, lack of employable skills, 
restricted mobility due to inadequate transport services, and lack of employment opportunities in the regions. Most 
of the unemployed people find work in seasonal agricultural activities or in daily paid casual labor work or else as 
sharecroppers to support their families. A fair number of children also work in various factories to find extra incomes 
for their families despite child labor being illegal. Most of the women are housewives but they would engage in 
agriculture, livestock farming, tailoring and manufacture of handicrafts to earn a supplementary income for their 
families. The ADB Country Partnership Strategy indicates that women have lower rate of labor force participation, 
higher unemployment rates and have limited access to technical and vocational training (27.43% of students are 
female) 
2.  Beneficiaries. The first component for transmission will support an increase of low-cost base load power to the 
national grid of Bangladesh and improve reliability of power in south and central Bangladesh including Dhaka. The 
second project component involving service improvement in parts of Dhaka and reducing customer outages will

Appendix 1  9 
benefit over 700,000 customers (2015) served by the Dhaka Electric Supply Company. The third project component 
of distribution system rehabilitation, augmentation and rural electrification in Bangladesh Rural Electricity Board 
(BREB) service areas will benefit a significant cross section of electricity consumers and the rural households 
served by BREB through its network of 77 palli bidyut samitis (PBS or rural cooperatives). It is estimated that 
expansion of the rural electrification schemes will enable connecting more than 950,000 new consumers and 
enhance capacity to existing consumers. The fourth component will benefit several power sector agencies to 
enhance their institutional capacities and efficiency of service delivery including on areas such as efficiency 
improvement of utilities and tariff setting. The additional finance will improve distribution systems for existing 
customers in the Khulna district through rehabilitation works. 
3.  Impact channels. The new power generation, improved quality and reliability and the expansion of the power 
supply in rural areas will help to reduce domestic demand for kerosene and petroleum from international markets. 
The proposed project will indirectly enhance the quality of life and health of the population of Bangladesh. The 
households connected to electricity will benefit from cost savings on energy and increased convenience in their 
household chores, economic activities, and studies, and will promote the use of energy-based technologies for 
economic activities, education, and entertainment. The farmers who suffer from crop losses due to poor and costly 
irrigation systems will use electricity for irrigation to reduce production costs and crop losses, and for mechanization 
of traditional modes of production. The increased capacity and efficiency of the transmission network, including the 
distribution improvements will underpin national economic growth and community prosperity and eventually reduce 
poverty. 
4.  Other social and poverty issues. In the informal sector of the subproject impact areas, daily wages paid to 
women who engage in casual labor work are lower than the wages paid to men although there is not much 
difference in the workload that both groups carry out. Excess of the labor available and social attitudes towards 
women are reported as factors that influence the lower wages for women. The access to educational and 
employment opportunities is restricted due to household poverty, socio-cultural barriers, and limited transport 
facilities. Opportunities for acquiring technical and vocational skills are rather remote in the villages and accessing 
such training in urban areas is unaffordable to many families due to financial difficulties and lack of transport 
facilities. The facilities available in such places in terms of qualified medical and nursing personnel and medicine 
are in poor conditions. Awareness on HIV/AIDS is rather limited in most of the communities in the subproject impact 
areas except for a few people who gained some awareness through television and other media. 
5.  Design features. The project, including the additional finance is classified as a general intervention and is 
expected to have a positive impact on peoples accessing energy through improved and reliable transmission and 
distribution systems. No irreversible critical or adverse impacts were identified. The project will improve the overall 
energy supply and development of the country. The project will develop a strategy to avoid or minimize negative 
impacts on people and vulnerable groups directly or indirectly affected through appropriate management and 
mitigation measures including payment of adequate compensation for loss of land, structures, crops, and trees as 
applicable. 
II.  PARTICIPATION AND EMPOWERING THE POOR 
1.  Participatory approaches and project activities. Public consultations at 21 locations with the participation of 
285 men and women and their community-based organizations, and gender focused consultations at 19 locations 
with 233 women in the project impact areas were conducted during the preparation of the resettlement plan and for 
disclosing  information  about  the  proposed  project  and eliciting  their  views  and concerns.  Feedback  from 
consultations was fed into the project design and implementation procedures. The process of consultation and 
information sharing will continue throughout project implementation. 
2.  Civil  society  organizations.  Consultations  will  continue  with  all  stakeholders,  including  civil  society 
organizations, during project implementation. The transmission component will hire the services of a non-
governmental organization to implement the resettlement plan. The rural electrification component will be 
implemented by BREB and the PBSs. The PBSs are partners in the project implementation. In addition, the 
activities under the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction regarding the distribution and capacity building will involve 
community-based user groups in project implementation. 
3.  The following forms of civil society organization participation are envisaged during project implementation, 
rated as high (H), medium (M), low (L), or not applicable (NA): 
 
H  Information gathering and sharing  H Consultation  H Collaboration  H Partnership 
4.  Participation Plan. This is as identified in the resettlement plan where continued participation during project. 
III. GENDER AND DEVELOPMENT 
Gender mainstreaming category: Effective Gender Mainstreaming 
implementation would be carried out.  Yes     No

10  Appendix 1 
A. Key issues: Gender inequality is a major social issue that limits the life options of women in Bangladesh. Women 
constituted about 50% of the population in the 2011 census. Bangladesh was placed at a gender inequality index 
of 0.542 in 2017 and a ranking of 134 out of 160 countries reflecting high gender inequality with respect to 
reproductive health, empowerment (political participation and education), and labor market participation. In 2017, 
the labor force participation rate was 33% for females and 79.8% for males.f Estimated per capita incomes in 2017 
averaged $2,041, for women and $5,285 for men.g The link between gender inequality and energy supply has been 
cited. 
Overall, the energy sector is dominated by men, with energy industries employing very few women (about 2,000 
compared to 70,000 men). Moreover, because women are primarily expected to do household chores, they supply 
human energy to pump water and collect fuel for cooking in the absence of a domestic energy supply, resulting in 
diminished or lost opportunities for education, income earning, and leisure. The project outputs are designed to 
deliver tangible benefits to women by directly improving their access to social services, economic or financial 
resources or opportunities, and/or basic rural infrastructures. The associated technical assistance, funded by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, will specifically focus on addressing the gender issues in the PBSs including 
through (i) developing model energy-based livelihoods with a focus on women’s microenterprises development,    
(ii) providing end-user education for the safe and efficient use of energy,(iii) improving the environment in the rural 
electricity cooperative for women employees and subsidized customers, and (iv) providing technical and skills 
training, including in geographic information systems, to enable women to capture employment and livelihood 
opportunities in emerging areas. 
B. Key actions. A gender action plan (GAP) has been prepared to support on rural electrification related 
interventions and would be implemented along with support from the $2.0 million Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction. 
Performance targets and indicators have been matched to outputs and indicated in the GAP. The BREB PMU will 
oversee implementation of the GAP.

IV. ADDRESSING SOCIAL SAFEGUARD ISSUES 
A. Involuntary Resettlement                                    Safeguard Category: A    B   C   FI  
1.  Key impacts: The project and the additional financing will not involve any land acquisition or physical 
displacement of the population. However, temporary economic displacements are anticipated. The resettlement 
impacts of the project are exclusively confined to the transmission system development component, which will 
include temporary loss of crops cultivated in an area of about 562 hectares of private land, loss of an estimated 
4,661 standing and commercial trees with an average of 27 trees per acre, and disturbance of 0.17 hectare of land 
by the erection of transmission towers and stringing of transmission lines. As a result, a maximum of 2,180 
households might be temporarily affected, but the overall impact of the losses on households’ economy and living 
standards will be marginal. None of the other three project components will have significant resettlement impacts. 
Impacts associated with the additional finance relate to refurbishment of distribution poles and lines are minor and 
limited to potential temporary economic displacement during civil works; and any such impacts will be confirmed 
through due diligence activities.   
2.  Strategy to address the impacts: A resettlement plan has been prepared with an entitlement matrix and 
resettlement budget to provide compensation for the affected persons at replacement cost. For the additional 
finance, due diligence will be undertaken, and the result will be incorporated in the resettlement plan if needed.

V. ADDRESSING OTHER SOCIAL RISKS 
A. Risks in the Labor Market 
1. Relevance of the project for the country’s or region’s or sector’s labor market.

2. Labor market impact: The project will create temporary employment opportunities for skilled and unskilled labor 
in the subproject areas during its construction. The contractual work agreements with engineering construction 
companies will include conditions for contractors to ensure the deployment of local labor wherever possible, 
maintaining gender equality in labor force participation and compliance with core labor standards including equal 
wages and benefits to men and women for work of equal value, and health and safety measures for the labor force. 
B.  Affordability: No issue anticipated. 
C. Communicable Diseases and Other Social Risks 
1. Indicate the respective risks, if any, and rate the impact as high (H), medium (M), low (L), or not applicable (NA) 
   Communicable diseases   Human trafficking   Others (please specify __________________ 
2. Describe the related risks of the project on people in project area. 
Risks of the project on local communities are perceived to be minimal. The project, including the additional finance 
investments will generate employment opportunities for the local communities. The executing agencies will ensure 
compliance with labor laws, with no child labor employed. Workers will be educated on the prevention of sexually 
transmitted infections including HIV/AIDS. Worker camps (if necessary) will be set up outside the settlements and 
deployment of child labor and human trafficking will be strictly prohibited.  
VI.  MONITORING AND EVALUATION 
1. Targets and indicators: The monitoring and evaluation indicators will include (i) conduct of consultations with 
affected persons, other stakeholders and their participation; (ii) status of information disclosure; (iii) timely payment 
of compensation; (iv) grievance redress; (v) measures to avoid construction related losses and disturbances to 
local communities; (vi) economic and social benefits to local communities; and (vii) sex-disaggregated data on 
participants of consultations, project staff and workers, recipients of economic and social benefits of the project. 
2. Required human resources: Staff for the project management unit (PMU), project managers and their staff in 
project implementation units, and hired consultants. 
3. Information in the project administration manual. 
4. Semi-annual monitoring reports by the PMU. 
5. Monitoring tools: Monitoring reports will be submitted by PMU and project implementation units, and ADB will 
review the reports and conduct site visits if necessary. These will include details related to social aspects of the 
additional finance investments.
